content: British historian and colonial advisor (1880–1966) Sir **Roland St. John Braddell** (20 December 1880 – 15 November 1966) was a historian and colonial adviser in [British Malaya](/wiki/British_Malaya). He was considered "one of Malaya's foremost legal authorities". ## Early life Roland St. John Braddell was born in [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore_in_the_Straits_Settlements#Crown_colony_(1867–1942)) in 1880. His father, [Thomas de Multon Lee Braddell](/wiki/Thomas_de_Multon_Lee_Braddell), had served as [Attorney-General of Singapore](/wiki/Attorney-General_of_Singapore), as had [his father](/wiki/Thomas_Braddell) before him.: 1–2 He was educated at [King's School, Canterbury](/wiki/King%27s_School,_Canterbury), and then [Worcester College, Oxford](/wiki/Worcester_College,_Oxford).: 2 He was [called to the bar](/wiki/Called_to_the_bar) in 1905. ## Writing career Braddell wrote several books on the history of [Malaya](/wiki/British_Malaya),: 78 as well as a two-volume legal work called *Laws of the Straits Settlements* and a book titled *Gaming Laws*. Alongside this, he published several essays concerning the legal status of the [Federated Malay States](/wiki/Federated_Malay_States) from a series of lectures he had given to the Singapore Rotary Club. He worked as an editor on *One Hundred Years of Singapore* with [Walter Makepeace](/wiki/Walter_Makepeace) and [Gilbert Brooke](/wiki/Gilbert_Brooke).: 6–7 Alongside editing the book, he contributed several chapters to it. In 1934, he published *The Lights of Singapore*, an anecdotal work on life in the region.: 7 ## Educational career Braddell served as Chairman for the Council of the [University of Malaya](/wiki/University_of_Malaya) in Singapore from 1949. He was later knighted for his work in this position, and also granted the degree of Honorary [Doctor of Letters](/wiki/Doctor_of_Letters).: 7 Following his retirement from the university in 1951, he returned to [Kuala Lumpur](/wiki/Kuala_Lumpur).: 7–8 In 1953, alongside [R. G. D. Allen](/wiki/R._G._D._Allen), Braddell was appointed to "submit a scheme of courses and organisation for consideration by Senate and Council" at the University of Malaya. In March 1955, they published the Braddell-Allen Report and recommended the creation of two new departments for Social Sciences and Law. Braddell proposed a four-year programme with various elements to it, and consulted with legal experts like the Bar Committee of Singapore over what to include. He also suggested that a Professor of Law be hired by the university to develop a curriculumm, and [Lionel Astor Sheridan](/wiki/Lionel_Astor_Sheridan) was hired soon after.: 240–1 He was a Life Fellow of The [Asiatic Society](/wiki/Asiatic_Society) since 1934, and served as President of its Malayan branch for several years. ## Colonial career Braddell served as Municipal Commissioner in Singapore for several years during [World War I](/wiki/World_War_I), and later became a member of the Housing Commission and the Executive Council. From 1932 to 1940, he was a Constitutional Advisor and member of the Executive Council to the [Sultan of Johore](/wiki/Sultan_of_Johore). Following [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II), he advised the [United Malays National Organisation](/wiki/United_Malays_National_Organisation) (UMNO) and the [monarchies of Malaysia](/wiki/Monarchies_of_Malaysia).: 8 ## Personal life Braddell died on 15 November 1966.: 1
title: Roland Braddell
